entry.title: How I manage my layouts
entry.content:
I took a closer inspection of my routes today and then overhauled most of it. My layouts are a nested parallel of an html document.

First the droll details of the html head. Anything rendered within this layout is at least styled.

html_and_head.slim
| <!doctype html>
html
  head
    meta charset="utf-8"
    meta content="IE=edge;chrome=1" http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible"
    title= current_article.title rescue 'adamwong246.github.io'
    = stylesheet_link_tag "normalize", "all", "github", 'http://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Raleway:400,200,700'
    = javascript_include_tag  "all", "vendor/bower_components/jquery/jquery.min"
    = javascript_include_tag "google_analytics"

  = yield
an example

Then the body. This is where the overall layout of the entire site is defined.

body.slim
= wrap_layout :html_and_head do
  body.HolyGrail
    header
    .HolyGrail-body
      #main.HolyGrail-content role="main"
        = yield
      nav.HolyGrail-nav.sidebar
        .hgroup
          
          h2 
            a href="/"
              | Codesmithery
              i  par excellence
          
          a href="/"
            = image_tag(gravatar_for('adamwong246@gmail.com'))
          
          h5
            a href="mailto:adamwong246@gmail.com" title='email'
              | adamwong246@gmail.com 

          h1.socials
            a.github href="https://github.com/adamwong246" title='githubalt'
              span.symbol circlegithubalt
            a.stackoverflow href="http://stackoverflow.com/users/614612/adamwong246" title='stackoverflow'
              span.symbol circlestackoverflow

          h1.socials
            a href="http://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=69760011&trk=nav_responsive_tab_profile" title='linkedin'
              span.symbol circlelinkedin
            a href="https://plus.google.com/104202656400776521456/posts?partnerid=gplp0" title='g_plus'
              span.symbol circlegoogleplus
            a href="https://twitter.com/adamwong246" title='twitter'
              span.symbol circletwitter
            a href="https://www.facebook.com/adamwong246" title="facebook"  
              span.symbol circlefacebook

          h3
            a href="/about_me.html" about me

          - blog.tags.each do |tag, articles|
            h4= link_to tag, tag_path(tag)

          h6
            - recent_post = blog.tags["posts"].first
            a href=recent_post.url
              | Recent post: 
              = recent_post.title

          h1.socials
            a href="/feed.xml" title="rss"
              span.symbol circlerss
              
      aside.HolyGrail-ads
        .footer-asider
          p
            | Adam Wong, 
            = Date.today.year 
          p
            | The thoughts and words expressed herein are mine alone and do not reflect upon my employer nor any other organization or individual. 
          p
            a href="http://www.wtfpl.net/" Released under the WTFPL
          p
            a href="https://github.com/adamwong246/adamwong246.github.io" source
          .signature
            = partial("partials/signature")
    footer.footer
an example

Finally, the post layout. This is what individual blog posts are rendered within. It really just outputs some yaml frontmatter like the date and title.

post.erb
<% wrap_layout :body do %>
  <article>
    <h2>
      <%= link_to current_article.title, current_article %> <span><%= current_article.date.strftime('%b %e') %></span>
    </h2>
    
    <%= yield %>

    <%= partial("partials/social_share") %>
  </article>
<% end %>
an example

Notice the separation of concerns. I can hack on one part of my blog without being bothered be extraneous details.

entry.title: github yoink
entry.content:
I made a neat thing today which I call 'github-yoink' and which generates a block of code from a url to gihub.

Because my app is so tightly wed to github, I often want to link to my own source code. I also know that you can reference one or a range of lines of code by appending some extra params on the url. You can link to an entire document resume.pdf.slim, a line in a document resume.pdf.slim#L1, or a block of code. resume.pdf.slim#L1#L8

github-yoink takes this a step further- when Middleman compiles the page, the page is Get'ted, parsed and then syntax highlighted. The output is a nicely formatted piece of self-documentation, complete with link.

resume.pdf.slim
- kit = PDFKit.new(partial("assets/markdown/resume"),
  :margin_top => 10,
  :margin_bottom => 10,
  :margin_left => 10,
  :margin_right => 10,
  :disable_smart_shrinking => false,
  :print_media_type => true,
  :dpi => 96)

- kit.stylesheets << 'source/assets/css/all.css.scss'
- kit.stylesheets << 'source/assets/css/normalize.css'
= kit.to_pdf
resume.pdf.slim#L1
- kit = PDFKit.new(partial("assets/markdown/resume"),
resume.pdf.slim#L1#L8
- kit = PDFKit.new(partial("assets/markdown/resume"),
  :margin_top => 10,
  :margin_bottom => 10,
  :margin_left => 10,
  :margin_right => 10,
  :disable_smart_shrinking => false,
  :print_media_type => true,
  :dpi => 96)

That's sort of meta but *we need to go deeper.* Let's use this technique on itself.

gh_yoink.html.slim
ruby:
  matches = link.scan(/#L(\d+){0,2}/).flatten

  doc = Nokogiri::HTML(open(link.gsub(/#L(\d+){0,2}/, '')))

  if matches.length == 0
    output = doc.css(".code-body.highlight pre .line").map(&:content).join("\n")
  elsif matches.length == 1
    output = doc.css(".code-body.highlight pre #LC#{matches[0]}").map(&:content).join("\n")
  elsif matches.length == 2
    output = (matches[0]..matches[1]).map{ |m|
      doc.css(".code-body.highlight pre #LC#{m}").map(&:content)
    }.join("\n")
  end

.titled-code-block  
  h6
    a href=link = link.split('/').last
  - code('ruby') do
    = output

How cool is that? Notice how this isn't a helper method, it's a partial! You call it like this (in slim)...

= partial('partials/gh_yoink', locals: {link: 'https://github.com/adamwong246/adamwong246.github.io/blob/middleman/source/about_me/resumes/resume.pdf.slim'})

I've said it before and I'll say it again: Helper methods are for suckers. Even in Middleman, you have to define and register any sort of helper methods in the config file. What a hassle! Meanwhile, partials make great method substitutes.
